headline: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

headline: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
abstract: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, though the discussions are said to be stalled because of a disagreement over valuations.

abstract: For every job opening in November, there were 6.35 people out of work, a record high.

abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

abstract: From Economix: Canada’s concentrated megabanking system is often held up as a model for why Americans shouldn’t worry about their own large banks. Two economists explain why this thinking is wrong.

headline: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
abstract: Immigrants may or may not compete with Americans for jobs, but they do help keep the Social Security system solvent.

abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

headline: And the Recaps of the Super Bowl Spots Just Keep on Coming
abstract: The Nielsen Company said that the most-watched spot in Super Bowl XLIV was one in the fourth quarter for Doritos, the snack chips sold by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, called “Samurai Snack Attack.”

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

headline: A.I.G. Imposes Limits on Corporate Aircraft
abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

headline: Colonial to Sell Up to $50 Million of Stock
abstract: Colonial Properties Trust said Thursday that it filed paperwork that will allow it to sell up to $50 million worth of its common shares through an ”at-the-market” offering, in which a broker executes a sale at the best price currently available, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Goldman Said to Take New Steps to Polish Image
abstract: Goldman Sachs has hired a public relations firm to help repair its tattered image, as insiders and clients worry about the effect the endless bad publicity may take on its profits, The New York Post reported.

headline: G.M. Hires AlixPartners to Wind Down Saab
abstract: General Motors took another step toward winding down its Saab brand by hiring the consulting firm AlixPartners to supervise the process, even as bidders are emerging for the Swedish marque.

headline: Genii Withdraws From Bidding for Saab
abstract: Genii Capital, the investment company, has withdrawn from the bidding for General Motors’ unit Saab, leaving Spyker Cars as the sole remaining bidder to rescue the ailing Swedish auto brand.

headline: Forest Carbon Offsets in the Ozarks
abstract: Two offsets companies announced last week that they’ve joined forces to develop carbon offsets on 300,000 acres of forest land in the Ozark mountain region.

headline: Parents at Work
abstract: The portion of American children living in households where all parents work has nearly doubled in the last few decades, a new White House report finds.

headline: UBS’s New Code of Ethics for Employees
abstract: UBS released a new ethics guidebook for its employees Tuesday, taking a stand on financial crimes, especially tax evasion, as it seeks to get itself back on course after a year of legal troubles.

headline: CNN Names Candy Crowley New Sunday Anchor
abstract: CNN has named Candy Crowley the new anchor of “State of the Union,” the cable news channel’s Sunday morning political talk program.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, March 18
abstract: Google TV, Christiane Amanpour close to ABC deal and a new digitally minded chief executive at Barnes & Noble.

headline: Borders C.E.O. Resigns
abstract: Ron Marshall resigns as chief executive of Borders Group.

headline: Update: Wednesday’s Olympics Coverage Tops ‘Idol’
abstract: Based on the overnight household numbers, NBC’s coverage of the Winter Olympics on Wednesday night was expected to trounce “American Idol” in the ratings, the first time that will have happened since 2004.

headline: Many Calls for Avoiding Repeat of Bank Bailouts
abstract: The idea of requiring giant banks to develop contingency plans that would spell out their orderly demise in a financial crisis is gaining support from major international regulators. Go to Article from The New York Times>>

headline: Swiss Have Yet to Hand Over UBS Client Data
abstract: Switzerland has not yet handed over data on clients of UBS to the U.S. authorities as part of a probe into possible tax evasion among wealthy bank customers, a government spokesman said.

abstract: The battle over financial regulatory overhaul continues to heat up, with Senate Democrats accusing industry lobbyists of improperly portraying community banks as victims of the financial regulatory legislation, when Wall Street is writing the checks to halt the bill.

abstract: AllVoices, a citizen journalism site, has nabbed $3 million in a funding round led by VantagePoint Venture Partners, TechCrunch reported.

abstract: The legal battle over the EMI Group picked up steam on Thursday, as Citigroup sought to dismiss a lawsuit by the buyout firm Terra Firma, arguing that the case belongs in Britain, not in New York.

abstract: Soros Fund Management is planning to plant its flag in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

abstract: Goldman Sachs Group, whose record earnings in the first nine months of last year fueled public outrage, will probably hit a profit plateau in 2010, just as Morgan Stanley rebounds from its worst year ever.

abstract: PetroBakken Energy said that it had paid $262 million to buy Berens Energy, a company that has drilled just three wells on its oil lands, The Globe and Mail reported.

abstract: Edward H. Linde, a founder of one of the largest real estate investment trusts in the nation — and the behind-the-scenes partner of Mortimer B. Zuckerman — died on Sunday in Boston. He was 68 and lived in Weston, Mass.

abstract: Just days after receiving Food and Drug Administration approval for Silenor, biotech company Somaxon Pharmaceuticals made plans to sell 4 million shares to fund marketing of the insomnia drug, The Associated Press reported.

abstract: Donations from a host of hedge fund manager and venture capitalists helped Meg Whitman, the billionaire Republican gubernatorial candidate in California, raise more than $10 million in campaign contributions.

headline: The Times Announces New Roles for Two Senior Editors
abstract: The Times announced that Rick Berke will take over as national editor and Suzanne Daley will return to reporting, covering Europe.

headline: Madison Avenue Looks to Vancouver
abstract: With less than a month until the start of the Olympics in Vancouver, British Columbia, marketers are raising the curtain on their advertising plans for the Winter Games.

headline: Swiss Data Source Says Mossad Kidnapped Him
abstract: Hervé Falciani, the computer specialist formerly employed by HSBC and involved in its enormous Swiss data leak, says he was once kidnapped by the Mossad.

headline: Debating the Nuclear Waste Problem
abstract: Speaking at a nuclear energy conference in Washington Tuesday, representatives of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission suggested that a new, long-term policy on nuclear waste storage was sorely needed.

headline: Vinocur: In Germany, a Very Risky Business
abstract: In its 2010 survey on Germany, the O.E.C.D. said German banking practice “exposes German banks relatively more to unexpected shocks than banks in other countries,” John Vinocur writes in his latest column.

headline: Greenpeace Takes Aim at Koch Industries
abstract: A new report from Greenpeace calls Koch Industries, an industrial conglomerate based in Kansas, a “financial kingpin of climate science denial and clean energy opposition.”

headline: Now Playing: A Trailer for ‘Wall Street’ Sequel
abstract: The trailer to Oliver Stone’s sequel to “Wall Street,” the touchstone of 1980s go-go finance culture, went online Thursday, giving a glimpse of what happens to financier Gordon Gekko once he is released from prison.

headline: Warren Says to Expect Commercial Real Estate Trouble
abstract: Elizabeth Warren, head of Congressional oversight for TARP and a major backer of the idea of a consumer protection agency, told CNBC on Monday that the U.S. economy still had a hard road ahead, with half of all commercial real estate loans set to be “underwater” by year’s end.

headline: SEB Squeaks By With Quarterly Profit
abstract: SEB, one of the Swedish banks with a major presence in the Baltic states, reported a fourth quarter operating profit on Wednesday of 564 million kronor ($77 million), a seventh of its 4 billion kronor profit a year earlier.

headline: HBO Go, the Best Online Video Service I Cannot Use
abstract: The service ignores the viewing habits of some Web-only video viewers.

headline: Associated Press to Create Pay Service for iPad
abstract: The Associated Press will create paid subscriptions through the Apple iPad for itself and other news organizations.

headline: When States Become Dependent on Federal Aid
abstract: Budget crises have made states dependent on federal largess, and in turn have given Washington more control over state spending, an economist writes.

headline: Keeping a Watchful Eye Over Davos
abstract: With the list of assorted dignitaries at the World Economic Forum, tough security is a necessity.

headline: At Tavern on Green, Everything Must (and Does) Go
abstract: Hundreds attended a tag sale on Friday to scoop up the last remnants of Tavern on the Green.

headline: Wednesday Reading
abstract: How one community is recovering from the recession, a look at Google’s new smartphone and other consumer-focused items from Wednesday’s Times.

headline: BlackRock’s Big Deal Gives Huge Boost to Profits
abstract: BlackRock’s fourth-quarter profit jumped nearly fivefold, thanks in large part to a huge influx in fees tied to the $1.85 trillion in assets it acquired by buying Barclays Global Investors.

headline: With Bridges’s Voice Silenced for Oscar Night, Hyundai Turns to the Rest of Hollywood
abstract: Hyundai Motor America is recruiting a number of Hollywood stars to pinch-hit for its long-time voice-over announcer, Jeff Bridges, for commercials that will appear during the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards.The substitution is required because of rules about the broadcast from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

headline: Bank of America’s Chief Seeks to Rebuild Trust
abstract: Bank of America’s new chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, said Monday that said the recession was fading and that the bank had finished making its biggest acquisitions, allowing him to focus on rebuilding relationships with customers.

headline: Lehman Paid Bankruptcy Advisers $642 Million
abstract: Lehman Brothers, which is being liquidated in bankruptcy, paid its lawyers and other advisers $641.9 million in 16 months since it collapsed in September 2008, according to a regulatory filing late Friday.

headline: Concerned Over Jobs and Revenue, Wall St. Wanders
abstract: Investors were cautious on Wednesday as concerns over high unemployment and the ability of businesses to bring in revenue resurfaced, tempering some of the zeal that had marked Wall Street earlier this week.

headline: Air Products Offers $5.1 Billion for Airgas
abstract: Air Products and Chemicals, a producer of industrial gases, has made an unsolicited $5.1 billion offer for a rival, Airgas, after having been rebuffed for months, The New York Times reported.

headline: A.I.G. Hires Finance Veteran to Oversee Risk
abstract: The American International Group said Monday that it has hired Peter D. Hancock, a veteran financial services executive, as an executive vice president overseeing the insurer’s finance and risk.

headline: European Central Bank Is Said to Consider New Rules on Swaps
abstract: The European Central Bank may try to get European Union rules amended so that countries can’t use swaps to cut excessive budget deficits, capitalizing on a debate sparked by Goldman Sachs Group’s swap arrangements with Greece, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Editorial: Bringing Back the Fixers
abstract: A plan by New York City’s freshly elected comptroller, John Liu, to ease a ban on the placement agents who help negotiate investments in the city’s pension fund includes a worrying step backwards, The New York Times’s editorial board says.

headline: As Fed Eases Loan Aid, Policy Challenges Arise
abstract: The Federal Reserve has terminated nearly all of the extraordinary lending programs it created in 2007 and 2008 to combat the credit crisis. But it now faces critical decisions in coming months about when and how to tighten monetary policy, according to two Fed officials.

headline: House Panel Seeks to Quiz Geithner on A.I.G.
abstract: A House committee is seeking to question Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner about why the American International Group was told not to disclose payments made to banks at the height of the financial crisis after the government bailed out the insurer.

headline: Europe Creates Apparatus to Provide Greece Loans
abstract: Finance ministers from the 16 countries using the euro as their currency said Monday they were ready to help rescue Greece, The New York Times reported.

headline: Hershey Said to Speed Up Cadbury Efforts
abstract: Hershey is stepping up efforts to prepare a bid for Cadbury and plans to make a decision after Kraft Foods’ final offer for the U.K. chocolate maker, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Wheels: Toyota Dealers in Five States Pull Ads from ABC
abstract: Wheels: Toyota dealers in five states pull ads from ABC.

headline: Shell to Join Brazil’s Cosan in Ethanol Joint Venture
abstract: Cosan, the Brazilian sugar and biofuel giant, said Monday it will merge its ethanol and fuel distribution units with Royal Dutch Shell in a joint venture worth up to $12 billion, extending the trend of growing foreign investment in alternative fuels.

headline: Apple Patent Application Could Presage Thinner Devices
abstract: An Apple patent tries to eliminate the need for separate touch-screen and LCD displays by merging the two technologies together.

headline: A Preview of the House’s A.I.G. Hearing
abstract: Ahead of a House committee hearing on Wednesday, more details are emerging about the government’s bailout of the American International Group in 2008 and why its trading partners were paid in full.

headline: Chinese Banks Said to Rein in Loans
abstract: Chinese banks have begun restricting new loans, responding to a push by regulators to contain credit after a surge in lending in the first half of this month, sources told Bloomberg News.

headline: Daytime Media Ready to Ride the Tiger
abstract: Tiger Woods, in a cage match with no opponent save himself, will preoccupy on- and offline media.

headline: Surprisingly Strong Job Figures
abstract: The jobs report is surprisingly positive. It should reduce fears of a double-dip recession.

headline: Plastic Logic Delays Its Que Tablet
abstract: Plastic Logic is delaying its $800 professional document- and book-reading device until this summer.

headline: Hedge Funds Lose Staff to S.E.C., Survey Finds
abstract: Findings in a new report that U.S. hedge funds lost staff to endowments and sovereign wealth funds may not raise many eyebrows, but one of the employers found to be siphoning off hedge fund managers may come as a surprise: the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Hyundai Drives for Super Bowl Superiority
abstract: One marque, Hyundai, is shaping up as perhaps the brand to beat in Super Bowl XLIV advertising.

headline: Bank of America Posts Loss for 4th Quarter
abstract: Bank of America reported a $5.2 billion loss for the fourth quarter of 2009, as the firm continued to weather increased mortgage losses and paid back billions of dollars in government bailout money.

headline: Irked, Wall St. Hedges Its Bet on Democrats
abstract: If the Democratic Party has a stronghold on Wall Street, it is JPMorgan Chase, but this year Chase’s political action committee is sending the Democrats a pointed message.

headline: Former A.I.G. Employees Might Sue Over Payouts
abstract: Several former American International Group employees might sue the insurer after it gave them less retention bonus money than they should have received, Reuters reported.

headline: Cadbury Stock Price Draws Closer to Kraft’s Bid
abstract: Shares in Cadbury fell again on Wednesday, edging closer to the level of Kraft’s $16 billion hostile takeover offer for the British confectioner. Meanwhile, some Cadbury directors have continued to hold back-channel talks with counterparts at Hershey over a potential rival bid.

headline: Kraft Seals Deal for Cadbury
abstract: Kraft declared victory on Tuesday in its pursuit of Cadbury, announcing that it has won widespread support from the British confectioner’s shareholders.

headline: Rush Limbaugh Released From Hospital
abstract: Rush Limbaugh announced that doctors have found nothing wrong with his heart or arteries, but the cause of the intense chest pains that sent him to a hospital remains unknown.

headline: Greece Mulls Bond Issue to Resolve Deficit
abstract: Greece is confident it can meet its financing needs as it grapples with a ballooning budget deficit and may issue bonds in yen and dollars this year to do so, top Greek officials declared Thursday, saying that the country could issue dollar and yen bonds this year.

headline: Lehman Settles Collateral Claims With JPMorgan
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings has agreed with JPMorgan Chase to settle about $7.68 billion in collateral obligations that were pending following Lehman’s bankruptcy filing in 2008, Reuters reported.

headline: Bulls in a China Shop: The East-West Divide
abstract: Samuel Huntington’s clash of civilizations has been a classic Davos theme. But if in the past the slogan has evoked images of the tumbling towers of the World Trade Center and bombs on Iraqi roadsides, this year the focus was on China.

headline: R.B.S. Sells German Unit to GE Capital
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday it has agreed to sell R.B.S. Factoring, a unit that provides loans secured against company invoices, to GE Capital, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Home of the British Grand Prix
abstract: Silverstone Circuit, the home of the British Grand Prix since 1950, will change the shape of the circuit at this year’s race in July. Meanwhile, F1 testing continued in Spain.

headline: Doostang Lands $1.25 Million
abstract: Doostang, an invite-only jobs Web site that claims to connect “the world’s most talented young professionals to exclusive career opportunities,” has raised $1.25 million of a targeted $2.1 million in its latest round of funding.

headline: JPMorgan Profit Rises Again, but Clouds Linger
abstract: JPMorgan Chase kicked off the latest, and highly anticipated round of bank earnings on Friday by reporting a $3.3 billion profit for the fourth quarter of 2009.

headline: Yitai Coal Said to Plan $1 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Inner Mongolia Yitai Coal, the Chinese coal miner, aims to raise about $1 billion from a Hong Kong initial public offering in the second to third quarter of 2010, a source close to the deal told Reuters on Wednesday.

headline: China Poly Seeks $1.4 Billion in Placement
abstract: The China Poly Real Estate Group, one of the country’s biggest property developers, plans to raise up to $1.4 billion through a private placement of shares to fund expansion.

headline: An Antitrust Investigation of the Banks?
abstract: From Economix: Instead of pursuing the issue of those “too big to fail” financial institutions exclusively through legislation, the administration could launch instead one or more serious antitrust investigations into the behavior of our biggest banks, economist Simon Johnson suggests.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Strong Results for Fourth Quarter
abstract: The hedge fund said its assets under management ballooned by $500 million in the last six weeks, according to its fourth-quarter earnings report.

headline: Sony Adds GPS and SD Card Support
abstract: Sony adds a pack of new features, including built-in GPS and support for SDHC memory cards, in new Cyber-shots.

headline: I.R.S. Commissioner Doesn’t Do His Own Taxes
abstract: Use a tax preparer? You are not alone.

headline: Can White Roofs Battle Global Warming?
abstract: Scientists created a model of the world’s cities and measured the impact on global warming if every rooftop was painted white.

headline: iPhone Remote Control Doesn’t Quite Click
abstract: ThinkFlood attempts to turn the iPhone into a universal remote, but it is just too hard to set up.

headline: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

headline: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
abstract: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, though the discussions are said to be stalled because of a disagreement over valuations.

headline: More Bad Job Market News
abstract: For every job opening in November, there were 6.35 people out of work, a record high.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Pledges Money for iPad Developers
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

headline: Canadian Banking Is Not the Answer
abstract: From Economix: Canada’s concentrated megabanking system is often held up as a model for why Americans shouldn’t worry about their own large banks. Two economists explain why this thinking is wrong.

headline: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
abstract: Immigrants may or may not compete with Americans for jobs, but they do help keep the Social Security system solvent.

headline: Q&A: Google’s Green Energy Czar
abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

headline: And the Recaps of the Super Bowl Spots Just Keep on Coming
abstract: The Nielsen Company said that the most-watched spot in Super Bowl XLIV was one in the fourth quarter for Doritos, the snack chips sold by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, called “Samurai Snack Attack.”

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

headline: A.I.G. Imposes Limits on Corporate Aircraft
abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

headline: NBC Announces Its 10 p.m. Schedule
abstract: Even as it faces uncertainty about its plans for late night after the Olympics, NBC announced changes to its prime time schedule that will fill the 10 p.m. hour being vacated by Jay Leno.

headline: Barclays Said to Help A.I.G. in Derivatives Deals
abstract: Not all the derivative contracts American International Group wrote on complex securities backed by now-toxic mortgages have ended up being a disaster.

headline: Bits Scan: Thursday’s Tech News Roundup
abstract: Over the last 18 months, hackers have breached more than 2,500 private and government computers, Kodak isn’t happy with Apple and Research In Motion, and David Pogue reviews Google Buzz.

headline: Ferrero Said to Discuss Cadbury Bids With P.E. Shops
abstract: Ferrero, the Italian confectioner, has met with private equity firms, as well as Hershey, to discuss a possible bid for Britain’s Cadbury, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

headline: Judge Approves Sale of Daytona Beach News-Journal
abstract: Despite being worth $300 million in 2006, a federal judge approved the sale of the Daytona Beach News-Journal for $20 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Viacom and Hulu Part Ways
abstract: Unable to make the digital media dollars add up to their liking, Viacom will remove “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart,” “The Colbert Report” and other Comedy Central television shows from Hulu next week.

headline: Ungaro Owner Said to Hold Talks With Italian Financier
abstract: The owner of Emanuel Ungaro, the French fashion label suffering under a load of debt, recently held deal talks with Matteo Marzotto, an Italian tycoon, The New York Post reported.

headline: Testing Ends in Jerez, as Bigger Tests Continue for USF1
abstract: The second week of testing in Jerez for F1 teams ended on Saturday with Jenson Button setting the fastest laptime in his McLaren. Meanwhile, the USF1 team continues its struggle to make it to the first races, as a team director told the NYT it would like to miss up to four races.

headline: U.S. Lawmaker to Push for Crackdown on Speculation
abstract: A key U.S. lawmaker, Senator Maria Cantwell of Washington, is set to join forces with several business groups on Wednesday to call for Congress to end the “reckless speculation” in commodity markets as the Senate prepares to take on financial reform.

headline: Rangers’ Sale Ends Months of Wrangling
abstract: The sale of the Texas Rangers baseball team ends months of wrangling between the Hicks Sports Group, headed by the former private equity maven Thomas O. Hicks, and the team’s debt holders.

headline: Shopify, a Start-Up, Starts Its Own Business Competition
abstract: The goal is to create fresh, new businesses — and customers.

headline: Hedge Fund Sues Icahn Over Bond Offering
abstract: Q Investments is suing Carl C. Icahn’s Icahn Enterprises over a propose $2 billion debt offering, as part of an ongoing legal battle between the hedge fund and the billionaire investor.

headline: Obama Plan: A 10-Year Bank Tax to Recoup Bailout
abstract: President Obama plans to call on Thursday for taxing about 50 big banks and major financial institutions for at least the next decade to recoup all taxpayer losses from the Wall Street bailout fund.

headline: Dubai May See Dawn
abstract: The Dubai government’s offer to recapitalize Dubai World and its subsidiary Nakheel means that the emirate may be close to ending its nightmare, Breakingviews says.

headline: Who’s Afraid of the Big Bad Deficit?
abstract: Government deficits are often criticized because of the purported legacy they leave for the future. At least when it comes to the Obama and late-Bush deficits, this legacy is exaggerated, an economist writes.

headline: With Euro Zone Pledge, Greece to Issue 7-Year Bonds
abstract: Greece is testing the waters again. The country’s debt agency said Monday that it had signed on five banks to underwrite a seven-year bond issue, just days after the major members of the euro zone and the I.M.F. agreed on a plan to support its debt.

headline: British Hedge Funds Unlikely to Sue Porsche
abstract: British hedge funds are unlikely to follow their U.S. brethren in suing Porsche, because they are striving to reach a compromise in Europe over tough new rules for the industry, Reuters reported.

headline: Surrender That Submarine
abstract: An accused Ponzi artist is jailed because he failed to turn over his submarine, among other things.

headline: Banks to Pitch the Wonders of Overdraft
abstract: Coming soon: A pitch from your bank to try to persuade you to sign up for overdraft services.

headline: Tip of the Week: Rescheduling With Google Calendar
abstract: How to use a new feature of Google calendar to reschedule events.

headline: Otsuka, a Japanese Drug Concern, Is  Said to Plan I.P.O.
abstract: Otsuka Holdings, Japan’s largest unlisted drug company by sales, is weighing an initial public offering and may hire Nomura Holdings and UBS as underwriters, bankers familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

headline: Buffett Is No Fan of Kraft-Cadbury Deal
abstract: Warren E. Buffett isn’t a supporter of Kraft’s revised bid for Cadbury, telling CNBC that if given the chance, he would have rejected the deal.

headline: France Confident It Can Tax and Retain Bankers
abstract: The French government does not fear that taxing bank bonuses will lead traders and financial operations to flee Paris, according to Finance Minister Christine Lagarde.

headline: In Leno-Letterman Ratings Competition, a Split Decision
abstract: NBC’s Jay Leno eked out a win over CBS’s David Letterman among total viewers, but among the viewer groups that NBC considers the real measure of success, Mr. Letterman was the winner.

headline: Samsung’s High-Performance Compact Camera
abstract: Samsung has announced four new point-and-shoot cameras, including a high-performance compact with a very bright lens.

headline: Why Phillips-Van Heusen Is Buying Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: The chief executives of Phillips-Van Heusen and Tommy Hilfiger told DealBook on Monday that their $3 billion deal was the product of two and a half months of talks, but made sense to them from the get-go.

headline: What We’re Reading: iPad’s Price, EBay Thieves and Palm’s Decline
abstract: Today’s reading list includes a cable company getting into the local blogs, discussions over who has more influence and more on the iPad.

headline: New Palm OS 1.4 Adds Video
abstract: Palm has added new features in its Web OS 1.4 upgrade. Here’s how to get it.

headline: Mixpanel Raises $500,000
abstract: Mixpanel, the developer of tools to track how users engage with websites in real-time, said Thursday that it had landed $500,000 in seed funding.

headline: DoubleVerify Pockets $10 Million
abstract: DoubleVerify, an online advertisement monitor, has nabbed $10 million in a second round of funding led by Institutional Venture Partners, PaidContent reported.

headline: Shares Gain on Earnings Reports
abstract: Investors rallied on Tuesday behind signs of stability in the housing sector and indications that businesses had bolstered revenue, lifting stocks for a second day.

headline: Buying Spree Nets China Stakes in Top U.S. Firms
abstract: Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, China’s sovereign wealth fund quietly snapped up more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citigroup.

headline: How Much Can You Stick on Flickr?
abstract: Flickr lets you upload 100 megabytes of photos each month free. Pro accounts give you more space.

headline: UBS Names Executives to Run Fixed-Income Unit
abstract: UBS has named Rajeev Misra and Dimitri Psyllidis to run its debt, currencies and commodities unit, which the Swiss bank is trying to expand.

headline: Merkel and Juncker Take Swipe at Credit Default Swaps
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Tuesday that the European Commission may have to decide on whether and how to regulate credit default swaps, the derivatives traders have been using to bet against the ability of certain European Union countries to service their debt.

headline: Who Belongs to Unions?
abstract: A detailed break-down of where the country’s union workers were employed in 2009.

headline: Looking Forward, Looking Back
abstract: A look back and a look forward in Formula One.

headline: Former Deutsche Trader May Soon Open a Fund
abstract: A former Deutsche Bank executive is planning to launch a hedge fund that would capitalize on mispriced securities in the Asian equity and credit markets, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Insider Suspect Said to Be U.K. Government Adviser
abstract: One of the men arrested in the insider trading inquiry in London also helped advise the British government on its stakes in Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group, The Financial Times reported Thursday.

headline: A Boom in ‘Distributed’ Solar Projects
abstract: Over the past few weeks, some 1,300 megawatts’ worth of distributed solar deals and initiatives have been announced or approved.

headline: I.B.M. Opens Energy Lab in Beijing
abstract: The technology giant aims to develop smart grid software for deployment in China — and eventual expansion to the global market.

headline: Cedar Fair’s Management Entry Ticket
abstract: The Deal Professor examines the involvement of Cedar Fair’s top management in the buyout of the amusement park operator and makes the case that this is a going-private transaction under the federal securities laws.

headline: Allah – the Word
abstract: In the Middle East, colloquial Arabic, drawn from the millennia-old tongue in which Muslims believe God spoke to Muhammad, has yet to become a battleground.

headline: Chinalco and Rio Tinto Team Up for Guinea Ore
abstract: Nine months after they scrapped a $19.5 billion tie-up, the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto and Chinalco of China reached a deal Friday to jointly develop an iron ore project in the West African country of Guinea.

headline: Battery Ventures Raises a Fresh $750 Million
abstract: Battery Ventures, the venture capital firm with offices in Massachusetts, Silicon Valley and Israel, has closed a $750 million fund, the firm’s ninth, Bits reported.

headline: Guvera, a Music Site, Lands $20 Million
abstract: Guvera, an ad-supported music site, has landed $20 million in a fresh round of funding from AMMA Private Investment, an Australian consortium of private angel investors, Tech Crunch reported.

headline: Losses Cause Plunge in Endowments, Study Finds
abstract: Reflecting the difficult financial environment for higher education, university endowments lost an average of 18.7 percent in the last fiscal year, the worst returns since the Great Depression, according to a study of hundreds of public and private institutions.

headline: In Hollywood, Grappling With Studios’ Lost Clout
abstract: A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week.

headline: Air Products Begins Tender Offer for Airgas
abstract: Air Products on Thursday began a $5.1 billion tender offer for Airgas, taking its $60 per share all-cash proposal directly to its target’s shareholders two days after being rejected again.

headline: Legal Broadsides Kick Off Air Products-Airgas Battle
abstract: Less than 24 hours after Air Products said it was making an unsolicited $5.1 billion takeover offer for its smaller rival, Airgas, the lawsuits started flying.

headline: Lehman Now Seeks $11 Billion From Barclays
abstract: Lehman Brothers, which is being liquidated in bankruptcy, said Thursday that it was now seeking a total of $11 billion from Barclays of Britain, including a $5 billion “windfall” that the firm contends Barclays received when it bought Lehman’s North American brokerage.

headline: Yahoo Offers New iPhone Search Applications
abstract: Yahoo announced two new mobile search applications for the Apple iPhone, including one that allows users to draw a boundary on a map to bring up localized content.

headline: Broken Record: Music Chief Is Out at EMI
abstract: The chief executive of a troubled recorded music division is stepping down.

headline: How the Health Care Law Affects Your Business
abstract: Answers to questions from small-business owners about how the provisions of the act will affect them.

headline: Michael Jackson’s Estate Signs Sweeping Contract
abstract: Nine months after Michael Jackson’s death, his estate has signed one of the biggest recording contracts in history, giving Sony, Mr. Jackson’s longtime label, the rights to sell his back catalog and draw on a large vault of unheard recordings, The New York Times reported.

headline: Mancessions, Around the World
abstract: Men have borne the brunt of job losses in most developed countries.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Let Bank Rules Slip After 2003 Case
abstract: The separation of the investment banking and research departments of large lenders just got weaker, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: With Lawsuits Settled, Jon Gosselin Could Return to TLC
abstract: Dueling lawsuits between the reality star and TLC have been settled, potentially reopening the door to more shows from the famous family.

headline: Warren Buffett Rocks Out
abstract: Warren E. Buffett has long been regarded as the biggest rock star in the financial world. But in a video made by employees of Geico, he decides to just rock out.

headline: F.D.I.C. Needs to Do Some Zombie Hunting
abstract: Killing zombies isn’t just a job for horror movie heroines. It’s also the primary task of Sheila C. Bair, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

abstract: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, though the discussions are said to be stalled because of a disagreement over valuations.

abstract: For every job opening in November, there were 6.35 people out of work, a record high.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Pledges Money for iPad Developers
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

abstract: From Economix: Canada’s concentrated megabanking system is often held up as a model for why Americans shouldn’t worry about their own large banks. Two economists explain why this thinking is wrong.

abstract: Immigrants may or may not compete with Americans for jobs, but they do help keep the Social Security system solvent.

abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

headline: And the Recaps of the Super Bowl Spots Just Keep on Coming
abstract: The Nielsen Company said that the most-watched spot in Super Bowl XLIV was one in the fourth quarter for Doritos, the snack chips sold by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, called “Samurai Snack Attack.”

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

headline: A.I.G. Imposes Limits on Corporate Aircraft
abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

headline: Swiss Banks May Have Lost Billions With Amnesty
abstract: UBS, Credit Suisse Group and Julius Baer Group — Switzerland’s biggest wealth managers — may have lost as much as $17.6 billion in assets through an Italian tax amnesty, Morgan Stanley estimates, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Bids in Hand, MGM Weighs Its Options
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the beleaguered film studio, said in a statement late on Monday that it has received a number of bids as it tries to reorganize its nearly $4 billion debt load.

headline: At South by Southwest, a Spotlight on Navigation
abstract: Today’s Media Decoded video suggests that the best use of online technologies, like those featured at SXSW, are in the offline world.

headline: When Private Equity’s Geniuses Fail
abstract: Scott M. Sperling, the co-president of THL Partners, told an audience at the Super Return 2010 conference that the market has constantly boomed and busted. And each time the cause is essentially the same: success leads to excess — even for the brightest investors.

headline: Greece to Seek Details on Loans From Europe
abstract: Greece received a welcome vote of confidence on Tuesday from the rating agency Standard & Poor’s for its deficit-reduction efforts, but the country was still pressing for details on a new loan rescue package from fellow euro-zone members, which remain divided over how it might work.

headline: Morgan Stanley Evaluates Hedge Fund Holdings

headline: ‘That’s the Ticket,’ Winfrey Magazine Declares

headline: Schlumberger Taps $1 Billion Deal for Geoservices
abstract: Schlumberger said Wednesday that it bought a French oil services company for $1.07 billion, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Richard Wright’s Estate Calls Google Book Settlement ‘Grievously Flawed’
abstract: The estate of the author Richard Wright has declared the Google Book Settlement to be “grievously flawed.”

headline: Energy Department Awards $187 Million for Development of Efficient Cars and Trucks
abstract: United States Energy Secretary Steven Chu announced the awards Monday, which will go to nine fuel-efficiency projects.

headline: Top Legal Officer Stepping Aside at Morgan Stanley
abstract: Morgan Stanley said Tuesday that its chief legal officer, Gary G. Lynch, was stepping aside to concentrate on his duties as vice chairman in London, working with regulators overseas.

headline: Merrill’s Fickle Fancy?
abstract: At least one legacy of the old Merrill Lynch is thriving at Bank of America, Breakingviews says: the kiss-off then embrace-back, Breakingviews says.

headline: Blair Signs Speaking Deal With Lansdowne
abstract: The British media are atwitter with the news that former Prime Minister Tony Blair is set to reap hundreds of thousands of pounds through a speaking contract with Lansdowne Partners, the U.K. hedge fund.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Trader of Taking Kickbacks
abstract: A former stock loan trader at Morgan Stanley and Bank of America in New York received well over $100,000 of cash kickbacks by steering orders to other brokerage firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed Tuesday.

headline: Bank of China Mulls Hong Kong Offering
abstract: Bank of China, planning a $5.9 billion convertible bond sale on the mainland, told analysts it may raise additional capital by selling new shares in Hong Kong.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Gains in 2009
abstract: Och-Ziff Capital Management, the publicly-traded hedge fund manager run by Daniel Och, said its flagship OZ Master Fund rose 1.1 percent in December to end the year up 23 percent.

headline: The Race Is On to Develop Green, Clean Technology
abstract: To top officials and business executives here at the World Economic Forum, Topic A this year was the race to develop greener, cleaner technology, which is emerging as one of the critical factors in reshaping the world economy.

headline: Tax Enforcers Intensify Focus on Multinationals
abstract: Tax inspectors are intensifying their scrutiny of multinational businesses, specifically taking aim at an arcane area of international accounting called transfer pricing.

headline: War@WSJ: New Book Pulls Back Blankets on Murdoch’s Capture of The Journal
abstract: New book by former Journal media writer goes deep behind the scenes of the Murdoch acquisition of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 23
abstract: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 23

headline: New Castle Exec to Plead Guilty in Galleon Case
abstract: Prosecutors in the insider trading case surrounding the Galleon Group told a federal judge Tuesday that Mark Kurland, a co-founder of New Castle Funds, had waived an indictment, an indication he intends to plead guilty in the case.

headline: Schapiro Says S.E.C. Is Looking Beyond Lehman
abstract: Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, confirmed Wednesday that the agency was investigating several companies’ actions in the run-up to the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Wall Street Pay Is a Focus of Many in Washington
abstract: Washington officials are waging pointed, if calculated, assaults on the billions of dollars in bonuses that banks are preparing to mete out — and, in many cases, hoping to turn the politics of pay to their advantage.

headline: Greenberg to Sell A.I.G. Shares to UBS
abstract: The former chief executive of American International Group, Maurice Greenberg, reached a deal to sell most of the shares he holds in the insurer to a unit of Swiss bank UBS.

headline: TARP Panel Finds Fault With GMAC Bailouts
abstract: A Congressional panel, in a report to be released Thursday, questioned the need for the Treasury Department’s $17.2 billion bailout of GMAC as the company dealt with the collapsing mortgage market in 2008 and 2009.

headline: Monday Reading
abstract: Why cable fees are going up, the industry effort to make digital video downloads as portable as DVDs and other consumer-focused items from Monday’s Times.

headline: Rusal Shares Slide in Hong Kong Debut
abstract: Shares in Rusal, the Russian aluminum giant, fell 9 percent in their landmark trading debut in Hong Kong on Wednesday, weighed down by a broad market slump that has seen many of the world’s leading stock indexes fall.

headline: TripIt Raises Money to Manage Itineraries
abstract: TripIt, a Web and mobile travel planning service, has raised $7 million in venture capital.

headline: HCA to Pay Its Owners $1.75 Billion Dividend
abstract: HCA’s private equity owners must be feeling a bit richer after the hospital operator said Friday that it would be paying them a $1.75 billion dividend.

headline: Airport Built, It’s Time to See if the Traffic Comes
abstract: Northwest Florida Beaches International, the first new international airport in the United States in more than decade, is also noteworthy because it is perhaps more of a real estate project than an effort to address a pressing transportation problem, The New York Times writes.

headline: Programmer Indicted in Goldman Code Theft Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors said that Sergey Aleynikov, a former computer programmer at Goldman Sachs, had been indicted on charges that he stole proprietary software that the firm uses to make rapid-fire trades.

headline: Former Homestore Chief to Admit Fraud Conspiracy
abstract: The former chairman and chief executive of Homestore.com on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to conspiring to commit securities fraud in a scheme to inflate the company’s revenue to win over Wall Street analysts.

headline: Cautious Steps Expected on Bank Liquidity in Europe
abstract: The European Central Bank is likely to outline additional steps on Thursday to siphon off more of the huge amounts of cash it provided to banks during the financial crisis, while carefully trying to avoid upsetting the still-fragile system and economic recovery.

headline: Goldman Acknowledges Conflicts With Clients
abstract: A senior Goldman Sachs executive sent an e-mail to clients on Tuesday disclosing that firm’s Fundamental Strategies Group, which often generates trading ideas, may have shared those investment strategies with the firm’s proprietary trading group or some clients before sharing them with others.

headline: Fox Drops ‘Little Genius’ Premiere
abstract: Fox will not broadcast episodes of a new quiz show featuring children, which was scheduled to have its debut next week.

headline: Brokerage Hopes for $2.5 Billion in Shanghai I.P.O.
abstract: Huatai Securities plans to raise as much as $2.5 billion in an initial share sale in Shanghai, where two companies that went public in the past month fell on their first trading day.

headline: What’s Your Ideal Job?
abstract: What’s your ideal job? If you’re like most employed Americans, it’s the one you already have.

headline: Ferrari’s Armchair Critic
abstract: Ferrari publishes scathing criticism of the state of Formula One less than a month before the season starts.

headline: I.B.M.’s National Security Play
abstract: I.B.M.’s purchase of a private consulting business may look humdrum at first glance, but it actually helps move the company into providing exotic services to the intelligence and military sectors — and yields a handsome payday for a defense-focused buyout firm.

headline: Carlyle Starts Renminbi Fund in China
abstract: Carlyle Group, the U.S. buyout giant, will partner with Fosun International, China’s largest non-state-owned conglomerate, to launch a yuan-denominated private equity fund, Fosun said.

headline: S.B.A. Stimulus Extension Lives, Then Dies, in Congress
abstract: The bill appeared ready to sail through the Senate without a formal vote, until Jim Bunning, of Kentucky, objected.

headline: What We’re Reading: Hacked Cars and E-Books for the Mac
abstract: Thursday’s roundup of tech gems includes a hacker who disabled 100 cars in Texas, Apple’s coming social networking service and a start-up that helps people find nonprofits.

headline: MediaNews’s Holding Company Exits Bankruptcy
abstract: Affiliated Media, the publisher of 54 newspapers that include The San Jose Mercury News, said on Monday that it has exited bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reports.

headline: E*Trade: Deal or No Deal?
abstract: Analysts appeared divided Monday on what the appointment of a new chief at E*Trade Financial meant for the takeover speculation that has been swirling around the company for some time.

headline: Seeking a Buyer, Swoozie’s Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Swoozie’s, a private equity-backed U.S. retailer of luxury gifts and stationery products, filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday, saying it was hurt by underperformance of recently acquired stores in the Northeast, Reuters reported.

headline: V.C.’s Prescribe $8 Million for Orbis
abstract: Orbis Education, a developer of nursing-education software, has received an $8 million injection. Lightspeed Venture Partners led the Series B round of financing for the Indianapolis-based start-up.

headline: Shell and PetroChina Bid $3 Billion for Coal Gas Firm
abstract: Arrow Energy of Australia said Monday that it had received a takeover offer worth about $3 billion from a company owned by Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina, the state-run gas and oil giant.

headline: In Iraqi Politics, Considering the Commute
abstract: Iraq may well be the only country in the world where a substantial number of its government officials actually live in other countries.

headline: Congress Worries About Commercial Real Estate
abstract: A bipartisan group of 79 House members sent a letter to the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve on Monday urging them to take a more active role in keeping the shaky commercial real estate market from turning into a disaster.

headline: End of Road Nears for BBDO and Chrysler
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., was formally named on Wednesday as the new creative agency for the Dodge car brand. Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, announced on Wednesday that it had been named the lead brand agency for the Chrysler nameplate.

headline: Martha Stewart Moves Her Show to Hallmark Channel
abstract: Martha Stewart is moving her talk show from broadcast to cable, signing a deal to provide programming to the Hallmark Channel.

headline: Ford’s Challenge to Gillibrand Splits Donors
abstract: Harold E. Ford Jr.’s potential bid for New York Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand’s seat has touched off a war for the city’s richest donors, especially those on Wall Street, as both camps race to nail down financial support and demonstrate the breadth of their Rolodexes.

headline: Fed Board Diverged on Timing of Policy Shift
abstract: Members of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making arm generally concurred that the central bank should eventually tighten monetary policy, but they disagreed on how to raise interest rates and reduce the balance sheet, according to minutes of last month’s meeting.

headline: March (Grading) Madness
abstract: A Sweet 16 bracket, based on grade inflation at different universities.

headline: For Bankers, Hearing Requires Walking a Fine Line
abstract: The bipartisan commission established by Congress to examine the causes of the financial crisis summoned the heads of four large Wall Street banks to defend their lending, risk management and pay practices and explain their role in the biggest economic downturn since the Depression.

headline: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

headline: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
abstract: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, though the discussions are said to be stalled because of a disagreement over valuations.

headline: More Bad Job Market News
abstract: For every job opening in November, there were 6.35 people out of work, a record high.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Pledges Money for iPad Developers
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

headline: Canadian Banking Is Not the Answer
abstract: From Economix: Canada’s concentrated megabanking system is often held up as a model for why Americans shouldn’t worry about their own large banks. Two economists explain why this thinking is wrong.

headline: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
abstract: Immigrants may or may not compete with Americans for jobs, but they do help keep the Social Security system solvent.

headline: Q&A: Google’s Green Energy Czar
abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

headline: And the Recaps of the Super Bowl Spots Just Keep on Coming
abstract: The Nielsen Company said that the most-watched spot in Super Bowl XLIV was one in the fourth quarter for Doritos, the snack chips sold by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, called “Samurai Snack Attack.”

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

headline: A.I.G. Imposes Limits on Corporate Aircraft
abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

headline: SpinVox, a Voice-to-Text Converter, Is Bought
abstract: SpinVox, a former high-flying British start-up that developed a system for converting telephone voice-mail messages to text, has been sold to an American software provider for less than a quarter of the valuation it once commanded.

headline: Two Fortress Executives Said to Leave
abstract: Two executives at a unit of the Fortress Investment Group’s liquid hedge fund business have left the firm, Bloomberg News reported Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Thursday Reading
abstract: The latest on the health care overhaul, the risks associated with various ways to pay online and other consumer-focused items from Thursday’s Times.

headline: A.I.G. Lines Up Underwriters for A.I.A. Offering
abstract: The American International Group has called upon virtually every major bank in Hong Kong to underwrite the initial public offering of its Asian life insurance unit, Reuters reported Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: A.I.G.’s Airline Leasing Chief Is Said to Be Leaving
abstract: The chief executive of International Lease Finance Corp., the airline leasing company of the American International Group, is expected to leave as soon as this week.

headline: G.M. to Halt Hummer Production Pending Sale
abstract: General Motors will halt Hummer production next week at its Louisiana plant until sale of the brand to a Chinese company is completed.

headline: A Boost for Contingent-Capital Deals?
abstract: The decision by the Netherlands’ Rabobank — one of the world’s most highly rated banks — to issue contingent capital securities could reinvigorate an idea whose popularity was waning, Breakingviews says.

headline: A Nuclear Critic Draws a Lesson from France’s Success
abstract: A new statistical analysis of an almost-secret topic — what it costs to build nuclear reactors in France — may have some lessons for a “nuclear renaissance” in the United States.

headline: Twitter Taps Pixar Executive as C.F.O.
abstract: Twitter named a chief financial officer on Wednesday, as the 2.5-year-old microblogging service steps up its efforts to make money.

headline: Radar Claims Two John Roberts Exclusives; One of Them Isn’t True
abstract: Radar Online claims an exclusive on Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts but quickly changes course.

headline: Stewart to Appear on ‘O’Reilly Factor’
abstract: Jon Stewart, the host of “The Daily Show,” will appear on the Fox News Channel’s “The O’Reilly Factor.”

headline: Arab Press Reaction to Ayad Allawi’s Election Success
abstract: Newspapers from the Arab world welcomed Ayad Allawi’s victory in the March 7 Iraqi parliamentary elections, anticipating a positive impact on the region at large.

headline: How to Succeed in Business Without Knowing Very Much
abstract: Over my head? You bet. But this is how a restaurant will come to exist in a space where no restaurant existed before.

headline: Developed Market Funds Suffer Redemptions
abstract: Investor concern about tightening lending conditions in China and deteriorating finances in Greece and Japan led them to pull cash out of developed-market equity funds for debt funds in the week ended January 27, according to fund tracker EPFR Global.

headline: Strikes and Lockouts at Record Low
abstract: Reflecting both the waning influence of organized labor and a dismal economy, there were just five major work stoppages in 2009.

headline: As U.S. G.D.P. Shrinks, Merger Rules Shift
abstract: U.S. antitrust regulators have lowered the dollar value of mergers that must be reported to the government to $63.4 million from $65.2 million, the Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday.

headline: Now in the Movie Marketing Mix: Six Flags
abstract: To help promote the release on June 11 by Columbia Pictures of a new version of “The Karate Kid,” there will be competitions at 10 Six Flags parks around the country to find the most talented karate students and their senseis, or teachers.

headline: D.O.J. Said to Examine Calpers Transactions
abstract: Justice Department investigators in Los Angeles are scrutinizing certain investment transactions of public pension funds, including the California Public Employees’ Retirement Fund, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Why E-Books Will Cost More
abstract: The Tech Talk podcast this week includes a discussion of e-book prices and offers some help with updating your BlackBerry.

headline: G.M. Chief Says U.S. Will Make Money on Bailout
abstract: General Motors will pay back roughly $8 billion in debt to the United States and Canada before June and could go public in a way that would allow taxpayers to make a profit on the bailout, Ed Whitacre said Wednesday.

headline: Obama Strikes Softer Note With Wall Street
abstract: In an exclusive interview with Bloomberg BusinessWeek, President Barack Obama took a conciliatory stance toward the financial sector, saying he did not “begrudge people success or wealth,” as it was “part of the free-market system.”

headline: Chrysler Near Deal to Buy Detroit-Area Plant
abstract: Chrysler Group is poised to acquire the Sterling Heights, Michigan, assembly plant for $20 million from the company that has managed the automaker’s remaining assets since its emergency from bankruptcy last year, The Associated Press reported.

headline: For the Unscathed Banks, China Beckons
abstract: A clutch of Western banks that have escaped the worst of the financial crisis are seizing the opportunity to ramp up their presence in China in the hope of profiting from the sector’s rapid growth, Reuters reported.

headline: Donations to Haiti May Be Deductible on 2009 Returns
abstract: If you’ve made a charitable contribution to help Haiti, you may be able to claim a deduction on your 2009 tax return.

headline: A New Tax on Banks and Bankers?
abstract: Does a new tax on financial institutions being weighed by the Obama administration make sense?

headline: Blockbuster Raises Possibility of Bankruptcy
abstract: Blockbuster, the video-rental chain, said Tuesday that for the first time, it may need to file for bankruptcy protection after years of struggling to lessen its debt load, Reuters reported.

headline: Dodd to Offer New Version of Regulatory Overhaul
abstract: Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said Thursday that he would unveil a new version of his financial regulatory bill on Monday.

headline: When House Prices Rise, Sales Fall
abstract: The December sales numbers for existing home sales show disappointing sales and higher prices, a reversal of previous trends.

headline: Krugman: An Irish Mirror for the Crisis
abstract: The financial crisis in Ireland offers clues about our own, and about how to prevent another one, Paul Krugman writes in his latest Op-Ed piece in The New York Times.

headline: App of the Week: Free Calls, if You Don’t Mind Ads
abstract: iCall lets you make free calls from your iPhone.

headline: JAL Draws Emergency Funds as Bankruptcy Looms
abstract: Japan Airlines moved a step closer to bankruptcy on Friday by drawing down $1.6 billion in emergency funding, with the prime minister set to decide when the carrier will start a state-led restructuring.

headline: Daring to Think ‘Private Jet’ Again
abstract: Gingerly, some business travelers are venturing back into private aircraft after the battered economy — and a public outcry against that perk of fat cats, the corporate jet — walloped the general aviation industry starting in 2008.

headline: Adam Ferguson – World Press Photo Prize
abstract: Congratulations to Adam Ferguson for winning first prize in spot news singles at the 53rd annual World Press Photo Contest

headline: Even in Bad Year, Firms Register for I.P.O.s
abstract: Despite the grim numbers on venture-capital-backed initial public offerings this last year, peHub says that there are 28 companies registered to price their I.P.O.s in the United States.

headline: To Curb Loans, China Tells Banks to Increase Reserves
abstract: Chinese regulators ordered state-owned banks on Tuesday to set aside a larger share of their deposits as a reserve against failed loans, another in a string of indicators that Beijing is concerned about speculation in the nation’s fast-growing economy.

headline: Editor & Publisher Sold to California Publisher
abstract: Editor & Publisher, the trade magazine that covers the newspaper industry, was sold to an Irvine-based trade show company and publisher of boating and fishing magazines Thursday.

headline: Microsoft’s Innovation Versus Dick Brass
abstract: Dick Brass, a former Microsoft employee, believes the company is becoming a failure and has lost its creative spark.

headline: Kurland Will Not Cooperate in Galleon Case
abstract: Mark Kurland, a former senior executive of New Castle Funds charged with insider trading in the Galleon case, has decided not to cooperate with investigators despite his expected guilty plea on Wednesday.

headline: Hershey Said to Bow Out of Cadbury Bid
abstract: Hershey, the U.S. chocolate maker, has decided not to launch a counterbid for British confectioner Cadbury following a unanimous vote by its board late on Wednesday, The Financial Times said.

headline: For Gamers Who Are All Ears
abstract: Two headsets cater to the gaming crowd. One even has special lights that show what side you are playing on.

headline: Korean Bank Steps Back From Global Ambitions
abstract: Korea Development Bank’s grand dream of breaking into the league of top global banks seems to have gotten harder to achieve, after its bid for an international foray was scuttled this week.

headline: Is All Fair in Love and Debt Collecting?
abstract: Business ethics is generally pretty straight forward. There are, however, occasions that make you stop and think. This is one of them.

headline: Testing Your Internet Speed: Advanced Edition
abstract: Other ways to check on the speed of your Internet connection.

headline: Wind Power Producer Huaneng Said to Plan I.P.O.
abstract: China Huaneng Group, the country’s largest power producer, plans to take its wind power unit public in a Hong Kong share sale this year worth at least $1 billion, four people familiar with the plan told Bloomberg News.

headline: State of Shock
abstract: Will bankers learn just how much they are resented?

headline: U.K. Minister Calls for Review of I-Banks
abstract: The U.K. Financial Services Secretary, Paul Myners, is calling for an independent review into the British investment banking industry to re-examine the “greed is good” culture that he says has spread through various corners of society.

headline: Google Gets More Social With Buzz
abstract: Google’s Buzz service, which ties into Gmail, is another way for people to tell others what they’re doing, thinking and feeling.

headline: One More Reason for Denials of Loan Modifications
abstract: Some troubled homeowners are being denied loan modifications for reasons that violate the Treasury Department’s rules, a new report says.

headline: Friday Reading
abstract: Toyota’s problems spread to Prius models, the latest on student-loan lender lobbying for subsidies and other consumer-focused items from Friday’s Times.

headline: Davos Bankers Seek One Message on Volcker Rule
abstract: A group of the world’s top banking chiefs and regulators, some nursing hangovers after a late night of party-hopping, finally started making some progress over financial reform at the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting.

headline: Leaving Money on the Table With the I.R.S.
abstract: Nearly 1.4 million people who didn’t file a federal income tax return in 2006 have only a few more weeks to claim a total of $1.3 billion in refunds.

headline: 6 Arrested in British Insider-Trading Inquiry
abstract: Two senior financial market professionals and a hedge fund employee were among six men arrested in Britain on Tuesday on suspicion of being involved in a sophisticated and long-running insider-trading ring.

headline: Asian Genco Fully Financed with $425 Million in New Funds
abstract: Asian Genco has raised $425 million, with funds advanced by a consortium led by Morgan Stanley Infrastructure Partners.

headline: Ackman’s Confidence Bolsters Borders Shares
abstract: Shares of the Borders Group jumped as much as 50 percent on Wednesday after its largest investor, William A. Ackman, said there was little likelihood that the struggling bookseller would file for bankruptcy.

abstract: As Haitians continue to reel from the massive earthquake that reduced much of its capital to rubble and killed an estimated tens of thousands of people, Wall Street firms are among the companies pledging millions of dollars to relief efforts.

abstract: PBS Newshour had a segment last week on economic humor.

headline: Schottenfeld Reaches Galleon Settlement With S.E.C.
abstract: Schottenfeld Group, the firm where three people charged in the Galleon Group insider trading case worked, agreed to pay $1.2 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, Bloomberg News reported.

abstract: Sunday night’s exciting game between the United States team and Canada was seen by 8.2 million viewers, a bigger audience than any NHL game on American television in 37 years.

headline: Big Oil Pursues Toreador Resources
abstract: Several big energy conglomerates are in initial discussions to buy or form a joint venture with Toreador Resources, an independent oil and natural gas company that operates primarily in France, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

abstract: QuinStreet, an Internet marketer that competes with Yahoo and Google, is the one beacon of hope in this week’s crop of initial public offerings as the market contends with jitters spurred by concerns about the economy.

abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

abstract: The Nielsen Company said that the most-watched spot in Super Bowl XLIV was one in the fourth quarter for Doritos, the snack chips sold by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, called “Samurai Snack Attack.”

abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

abstract: The upset Senate victory by a Republican in Massachusetts lifted the Fox News Channel last week to its highest levels in more than a year.

abstract: Spyker Cars, the Dutch maker of luxury autos, is still in talks with General Motors to buy its ailing Saab brand, but no deal has been reached, spokesmen for both sides said Monday.

abstract: Donald Trump, the larger-than-life real estate developer, and Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, took their contentious fight for the Atlantic City hotel-casinos bearing Mr. Trump’s name to federal bankruptcy court, Reuters reported.

headline: Carlyle Starts China Fund With Beijing
abstract: Carlyle Group announced that it’s teaming up with the Beijing government to launch a domestic Chinese private equity fund, Bloomberg News reported.

abstract: The Hartford Financial Services Group said Wednesday that it had paid back the $3.4 billion that the insurance company received in the government’s banking bailout.

abstract: Here’s more from one mutual fund shareholder advocate on how a proposed rule from the Labor Department varies from an earlier version and what it may mean for consumers.

abstract: A poem about overdraft fees. (No, really!).

abstract: Goldman Sachs was the most aggressive bank counterparty to American International Group, demanding more collateral while assigning lower values to real estate assets backed by the insurer, documents obtained by lawmakers show.

abstract: Opponents of financial reform may say they’re against bank bailouts, but what they are really trying to block is bank regulation.

abstract: Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge-fund firm, said assets fell 4 percent in the final three months of 2009 as its largest fund posted its first annual loss.

abstract: Fact-checking claims from the health-care summit meeting, and other links from around the Web.

headline: China’s Redgate Seeks $43 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Chinese advertising company Redgate Media Group will attempt to raise $43 million during an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

abstract: The Canadian mortgage insurance business of the American International Group will be sold to a private investor group headed by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, the group said Tuesday.

abstract: Venture capitalists, whose money provides fuel to technology start-ups, last year invested the lowest amount in such companies since 1997, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers and the National Venture Capital Association released on Friday.

headline: Wintrust Raises $182.9 Million in Offering
abstract: Wintrust Financial, which operates community bank subsidiaries, said Tuesday it sold 5.8 million shares in a public offering that netted about $182.9 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Intel Was Attacked at the Same Time as Google
abstract: Intel said it was the victim of a cyber-attack in January, around the same time that Google was a victim of a broad-based attack that started in China.

headline: Of Women, Sleep Deprivation and Financial Meltdown
abstract: Three male chief executives and three professional women argued at the World Economic Forum that gender parity was not just a worthy goal, but also an excellent business proposition.

headline: Guard Your Health Insurance Card
abstract: According to a new study, identity theft for the purpose of getting health care coverage may be on the rise.

headline: Government Priorities, Across the Decades

headline: Without Treaty, Pollution-Fighting Firms Set Course
abstract: Last month’s Copenhagen summit may have been a bust. But the topic may yet be revived at the World Economic Forum this week.

headline: Asia Leads the Global End to Cheap Money
abstract: The U.S. Federal Reserve kick-started its cautious exit from unprecedented emergency lending measures on Thursday — but the process has been going on for months in the Asia-Pacific region, underscoring the two-speed path of the global recovery.

headline: Kabul Bureau Chief Answers Readers’ Questions on Marja
abstract: Alissa J. Rubin, the Times’s Kabul bureau chief, is answering readers’ questions about the ongoing military operation in Marja, Afghanistan.

headline: Deutsche Boerse Said to Plan Major Layoffs
abstract: Deutsche Boerse plans to lay off up to 10 percent of its workforce as business in bonds and derivatives declines, the German financial daily Handelsblatt reports. The bourse, all subsidiaries considered, employs about 3,300 people.

headline: CA Acquires Nimsoft for $350 Million in Cash
abstract: CA, the technology management software company, said Wednesday that it’s buying Nimsoft for $350 million in cash.

headline: Report Says Value of Media M.&A. Fell 49%
abstract: The value of media and entertainment mergers and acquisitions fell 49 percent in 2009, according to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers.

headline: Comcast Is Absent From Campaign to Change Retransmission Rules
abstract: Comcast doesn’t sign a petition asking the government to change station retransmission rules.

headline: Ungaro Said to Seek Buyer
abstract: Emanuel Ungaro, suffering under a load of debt, is looking for a white knight, The New York Post reported.

headline: Wall Street Exchanges Turn Lower in Closing Minutes
abstract: Volatility returned to Wall Street on Monday, ending a four-day winning streak for stocks, as worries over the energy sector overshadowed hopes that banks would continue to bring in generous profits, The New York Times reported.

headline: British Ads Ignore Uncertainties of Climate Change, Watchdog Agency Finds
abstract: The British Advertising Standards Authority ruled that the government’s posters on climate change should have been “phrased more tentatively.”

headline: Success in Marja Will Hinge on Civilian Surge
abstract: The success of Operation Moshtarak will ultimately hinge not just on the actual clearing of Marja, but also on the hold, build, and transfer phases of the mission.

headline: Wrapping Your Head Around the Health Bill
abstract: An economist recommends some good resources to help people understand the health care reform legislation signed into law.

abstract: From Paul Krugman: Maybe the best way to think about the two financial regulatory reform bills currently on the table is to compare them to ancient armies, oddly enough.

headline: How Wall Street Helped Mask Europe’s Debt
abstract: Wall Street tactics akin to the ones that fostered subprime mortgages in America have worsened the financial crisis shaking Greece and undermining the euro by enabling European governments to hide their mounting debts.

headline: As India Sells Assets, Political Tensions Rise
abstract: In the last 10 months, India has raised $3.5 billion selling off pieces of state-run companies, more than such sales brought in during the previous four years.

headline: Putting In a Good Word for Algae
abstract: A European lobbying group is making its case for the environmental value of using algae to produce biofuels for vehicles.

abstract: EU nations are shutting major Wall St. banks out of their debt sales, The Guardian reports. No large U.S. bank ranks among the top nine leading the sales of sovereign bonds, according to data from Dealogic.

headline: Banks Prodded to Ease Lending to Small Firms
abstract: The Federal Reserve and other financial regulators, which have faced strong pressure from the White House and Congress to stimulate lending to small businesses, prodded banks on Friday to ease such financing.

abstract: The company that runs a virtual Hollywood stock market is creating a new Hollywood Stock Exchange that uses real money.

headline: Can We Afford to Continue Serving Small Clients?
abstract: As much as I like to help our small clients, we might have to start introducing them to other options if we want to meet our sales goals and remain profitable.

headline: Marketers on Facebook Find Photo Tagging
abstract: Marketers are making inroads into Facebook.

headline: Galleon Case Informant Faces S.E.C. Charges

headline: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take Meeker Tone

headline: Biomass Briquette Plant Opens in Cambodia
abstract: The country’s first factory producing fuel briquettes from biomass opened last month.

abstract: CF Industries’ surprise $4.7 billion bid for Terra Industries puts new pressure on the fertilizer maker, which has already accepted a $4.1 billion offer from Yara International.

headline: Obama Moves to Limit ‘Reckless Risks’ of Banks

headline: It’s Proxy Season: Will You Vote?

abstract: When finance ministers from the 16 euro zone countries meet Monday to discuss loan guarantees or loans for Greece, they are expected to strike a delicate balance by giving much-needed clarity on how a bailout could be structured while not making a rescue inevitable.

headline: California Officials Would Not Regulate Electric Car Charging Firms
abstract: Whether to treat such companies as quasi-utilities has been a contentious issue for some time.
