abstract: Three executives of the British unit of Alstom, the French transport and power equipment conglomerate, have been questioned on suspicion of bribery, corruption, money laundering and false accounting, British officials said Wednesday.

headline: Bank of America Hiring Said to Include Asia-Pacific
abstract: Bank of America has embarked on a major hiring spree across Asia, aiming to expand in the fast growing region and revive the investment banking franchise that Merrill Lynch built before the financial crisis.

headline: Clooney to Organize a Telethon for Haiti
abstract: George Clooney’s longtime publicist says the star is trying to organize a multichannel telethon to aid the nation.

headline: Videoplaza Reaps $5 Million
abstract: Videoplaza of Sweden, which makes software to help publishers optimize the distribution of their video ads, has rounded up $5 million, VentureBeat reported.

abstract: American Airlines upped its offer of investment in Japan Airlines by $300 million to $1.4 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.

abstract: Please keep those cards and letters coming.

abstract: A public service campaign to support relief efforts after the Haitian earthquake is already under way in what the Advertising Council, which oversees pro bono initiatives from Madison Avenue, calls its fastest response to a disaster.

headline: Goldman’s Flamand Said to Start His Own Fund
abstract: Pierre-Henri Flamand, the London-based head of Goldman Sachs‘s largest internal hedge fund, is leaving the investment bank to launch his own hedge fund firm, according to press reports.

headline: For Renters, Solar Comes in Shares
abstract: Renters are usually out of luck when it comes to solar power, but a new solution is springing up, in which utilities build large arrays and sell shares to customers.

headline: Morningstar Buys Footnoted, a Research Blog
abstract: Morningstar, the financial research firm, has purchased Footnoted.org, the financial blog that digs through S.E.C. filings to uncover buried news items.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Asks Review of Handling of Case
abstract: Lawyers for Bradley Birkenfeld, the former UBS private banker who is headed to jail for helping wealthy Americans evade taxes through secret offshore accounts, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to investigate whether prosecutors had mishandled his case.

headline: Tell Us How You Really Feel, Maureen
abstract: Maureen Dowd, the New York Times columnist, asks a long-running question about the NBC Universal executive Jeff Zucker.

headline: Investors Like the Looks of Stylesight
abstract: Stylesight, the fashion content aggregator and trend forecaster, has raised a $5 million tranche in a $10 million second round of funding.

headline: In Bank Plan, Geithner’s Views Lose Ground
abstract: The line-up as President Obama announced his plan on Thursday hints that he is not listening quite as much to Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner anymore, The Washington Post writes.

headline: What We’re Reading: Art Fraud, Steve Jobs and Citibank
abstract: Technology tidbits from around the Web selected by Times technology journalists.

headline: Administration Said to Settle on No. 2 at Fed
abstract: The Obama administration has chosen Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, to serve as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a senior administration official said on Thursday night.

headline: Harbinger’s Man at Times Co. Exits Board
abstract: An activist shareholder who joined The New York Times Company’s board of directors two years ago will relinquish his seat at the end of April, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Fed Official Prescribes Global Approach on Banks
abstract: The financial doesn’t address the systemic risk presented by the size of big banks, which ought to be reduced, Richard W. Fisher, the head of the Dallas Federal Reserve, said.

headline: In Galleon Cases, Timing Could Be Everything
abstract: The government’s standard practice of filing tandem criminal and civil cases is causing problems in the insider trading case against the Galleon Group and the billionaire Raj Rajaratnam, according to White Collar Watch.

headline: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

headline: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
abstract: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, though the discussions are said to be stalled because of a disagreement over valuations.

headline: More Bad Job Market News
abstract: For every job opening in November, there were 6.35 people out of work, a record high.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Pledges Money for iPad Developers
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

headline: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
abstract: Immigrants may or may not compete with Americans for jobs, but they do help keep the Social Security system solvent.

headline: Q&A: Google’s Green Energy Czar
abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

headline: A.I.G. Imposes Limits on Corporate Aircraft
abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

abstract: Anheuser-Busch, the division of Anheuser-Busch InBev that sells Bud Light and Budweiser beers, is changing its playbook in several ways for the coming Super Bowl.

headline: Private Equity Firms Brace for Tax Battle
abstract: Private equity firms are again being threatened with higher taxes, as a long-running debate over how to classify their profits again becomes a focus for governments desperate for cash.

headline: Chase (Sort of) Restores Lost Credit Card Rewards

abstract: Avis Budget Group on Tuesday said its rental car funding subsidiary completed a multi-class offering of about $580 million in asset-backed bonds, The Associated Press reported.

abstract: NBC and “Tonight Show” host Conan O’Brien continue to negotiate a settlement that will allow him to leave the network.

abstract: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has more than money in its quiver.

abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

abstract: In what resembled a scene ripped from the pages of one of his books, a crime writer was gunned down last month in broad daylight.

headline: Bin Laden Adds Climate Change to List of Grievances Against U.S.
abstract: The leader of Al Qaeda blamed developed countries for not halting climate change and said that the global economy should abandon its reliance on the American dollar.

headline: As ‘Worldfocus’ Ends, a Call to Save It
abstract: Like a similar campaign to save “Now on PBS,” the efforts for “Worldfocus” seem unlikely to succeed.

headline: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
abstract: Novartis’s bid to buy out minority shareholders in Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in the eyecare group said.

headline: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
abstract: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, though the discussions are said to be stalled because of a disagreement over valuations.

headline: More Bad Job Market News
abstract: For every job opening in November, there were 6.35 people out of work, a record high.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Pledges Money for iPad Developers
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is doubling its iFund to $200 million to invest in iPhone and iPad app developers.

headline: Canadian Banking Is Not the Answer
abstract: From Economix: Canada’s concentrated megabanking system is often held up as a model for why Americans shouldn’t worry about their own large banks. Two economists explain why this thinking is wrong.

headline: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
abstract: Immigrants may or may not compete with Americans for jobs, but they do help keep the Social Security system solvent.

headline: Q&A: Google’s Green Energy Czar
abstract: “As a society, we have chosen to invest too little in alternative energy,” said Bill Weihl, who steers Google’s clean energy endeavors.

headline: And the Recaps of the Super Bowl Spots Just Keep on Coming
abstract: The Nielsen Company said that the most-watched spot in Super Bowl XLIV was one in the fourth quarter for Doritos, the snack chips sold by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, called “Samurai Snack Attack.”

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
abstract: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research, hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital to lead the effort.

headline: A.I.G. Imposes Limits on Corporate Aircraft
abstract: For most of A.I.G.’s executives, flying on corporate aircraft is now a no-go, and even for its chief executive, riding on the firm’s dime has its limits.

headline: Foot on Bomb, Marine Defies a Taliban Trap
abstract: A near-miss with an I.E.D. began a journey through the Taliban’s tactics and led to an affirmation of friendship.

headline: Conflicting Demands Test Netanyahu
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel returned home with the politically explosive task of responding to an American demand that he limit building in East Jerusalem.

headline: Clinton Issues Another Warning to Iran
abstract: At the end of a regional visit, the secretary of state said that Iran’s program might set off a nuclear arms race.

headline: Shots Fired at Iran Opposition Leader’s Car, Son Says
abstract: The reported attack on Mehdi Karroubi, Iran’s most outspoken opposition leader, took place in Qazvin, where he had traveled to attend a funeral for protesters.

headline: Public Pension Funds Are Adding Risk to Raise Returns
abstract: Even as big companies are moving their pension funds out of stocks, state governments are chasing higher returns by making riskier investments.

headline: Lehman Says Debtor Claims May Decline
abstract: Lehman, the investment bank liquidating in bankruptcy, is evaluating 65,000 claims totaling more than $819 billion.

headline: Bank of America to Reduce Mortgage Balances
abstract: Bank of America said that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt of borrowers who could lose their homes.

headline: For Vilified Banks, a Pay Cut Might Be the Best Case
abstract: The public is so hostile to bankers now that there’s a risk of bad regulations. A step to rein in pay could head that off.

headline: Greece Pressed to Take Action on Economic Woes
abstract: European finance ministers gathered to put pressure on Greece to step up budget cuts and stem its debt crisis, but Greece, faced with growing public dissent, warned over doing too much too fast.

headline: A.I.G. Posts Loss of $11 Billion on Higher Claims
abstract: The insurance giant attributed most of its $11 billion loss for the year to a fourth-quarter charge taken to reflect that its bailout had been restructured.

headline: Management Shake-Up Continues at Disney
abstract: Oren R. Aviv, the studio’s top movie production executive, resigns under pressure after several top managers are ousted.

headline: Letter: Rating Greek Debt
abstract: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
abstract: A news analysis article on March 2 about an inquiry into a possible military coup attempt in Turkey that has highlighted the divide between the Islamic-inspired government and the country’s secular elite misspelled the given name of a Turkish preacher who leads an Islamic network that some critics say has undue influence on Turkish law-enforcement. He is Fethullah Gulen, not Fetullah.

headline: Wal-Mart Dispels Inflation Fears
abstract: Fears of deflation in the United States have abated, replaced by worries that rampant inflation could take hold. But the experience of Wal-Mart Stores, the world’s largest retailer, is a reminder that, for now, the battle on the ground is still against corrosive falling prices, not rising ones.

headline: Shares End Lower After a Day of Wandering
abstract: Shares tried but could not finish higher on Tuesday as a strong report on consumer confidence was unable to overcome concerns about the pace of the economy.

headline: Power Cuts From Drought Will Hit Manila
abstract: Utilities officials said the city of Manila and several neighboring provinces will experience blackouts in the coming days as the country’s energy crisis worsens.

headline: A Little Chip Designed by Apple Itself
abstract: With the A4 chip, Apple has challenged the norms of the mobile device industry, where chip design is usually left to microprocessor companies.

headline: Using Humor in a Campaign Supporting Disabled People
abstract: A national effort to encourage businesses to employ workers with disabilities is taking a lighthearted tack rather than a sober or earnest tone.

headline: Flush and Looking to Spend
abstract: After socking away cash to weather the crisis, the top 50 holders of cash in corporate America could be involved in deal-making.

headline: Glen W. Bell Jr., Founder of Taco Bell, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Bell’s idea in 1951 to sell tacos from his hamburger stand became the foundation of the restaurant chain that turned Mexican fare into fast food for millions of Americans.

headline: Afghan Police Kill 7 Mistaken for Insurgents
abstract: Villagers from Pakistan strayed too close to a border checkpoint and were killed when Afghan forces believed they were trying to overrun the post.

headline: Michael Foot Dies at 96; Led Britain’s Labour Party
abstract: Mr. Foot failed to broker a peace between the party’s left and right wings, and presided over its crushing defeat in the 1983 general election.

headline: A Little ‘i’ to Teach About Online Privacy
abstract: Trying to ward off regulators, the ad industry has agreed on a standard icon to tell consumers what is happening.

headline: App of the Week: Standing Guard Over a Lost Phone
abstract: Thoughts of cellphone security often dwell on the danger that hackers pose, but the far more likely threat comes from a phone that is simply lost or stolen.

headline: China Leads Better-Than-Expected Global Recovery
abstract: A report by the International Monetary Fund said that the recovery has been more vigorous than predicted, but that some developed economies would lag.

headline: O’Brien Rejects NBC Shift: He’s Set to Say Good Night
abstract: After NBC said it intended to move his “Tonight Show” to a new time, Conan O’Brien said he would not agree to what he saw as a demotion for the institution of the show.

headline: France: Nationality to Be Denied Over Veil
abstract: Prime Minister François Fillon said he would sign a decree denying French nationality to a man who ordered his French wife to wear the full Islamic veil.

headline: Andrew Jaffe, Who Brought Clios to Adweek, Is Dead at 71
abstract: Mr. Jaffe presided over the expansion of the advertising trade magazine and helped revitalize the industry’s awards for excellence.

headline: Financing Offered for Delayed Airbus Plane
abstract: Germany is prepared to offer up to 1.2 billion euros to help Airbus pay for cost overruns on the A400M military transport plane.

headline: Uproar in India Over Female Lawmaker Quota
abstract: A plan to reserve a third of the seats in India’s legislatures for women plunged Parliament into chaos and threatened the governing coalition.

headline: Talks With G.O.P. on Financial Bill at ‘Impasse,’ Dodd Says
abstract: Senator Christopher J. Dodd said that Democrats would forge ahead with their own bill, after months of talks aimed at reaching a bipartisan consensus.

headline: A Recovery That’s Factory-Built and Gaining Speed
abstract: As more manufacturers report increases in output and new orders, predictions of a slow recovery may turn out to be wrong.

headline: Universal’s Strategy Tests Lower Price on New CDs
abstract: The company will test whether lower prices — $10 or less — will attract consumers who have cut back on buying CDs.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The California Milk Processor Board, San Clemente, named Santa Susana High School, Simi Valley, as the winner of the grand prize in a contest to create video clips centered on an online rock opera that is part of the “White Gold” campaign for the milk board. The school won $20,000 for its arts programs. Pioneer Technical Center, Madera, won the second prize of $10,000.

headline: Medvedev Visits France in Bid for Closer Ties
abstract: Despite criticism from the U.S., President Sarkozy announced that France had entered “exclusive negotiations” to sell four amphibious assault ships to Russia.

headline: Do Chipmunks Outrank Na’vi?
abstract: “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” may be more valuable than “Avatar” over the long run.

headline: Issues Stand Before Israel in Joining Elite Group
abstract: The country's secretive weapons trade, patent-bending drug industry and occupation of Arab lands are raising questions about its accession to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: Clock Ticks for Nepal to Settle Its Future
abstract: An interim Constitution expires May 28, and no one is sure what happens if a new Constitution is not approved by then.

headline: Market Rises on Sense That Worst Is Behind Big Financials
abstract: Investors bought shares of firms bailed out by the government amid speculation that their balance sheets would substantially improve.

headline: Reform Bill Adds Layers of Oversight
abstract: Senate Democrats put forward a plan, with the backing of the Obama administration, that calls for Washington to play a more active role in policing Wall Street.

headline: Europe Weighs Oneworld Plan to Assure Flight Competition
abstract: The carriers British Air, American and Iberia offered regulators a proposal to ensure competition on some overseas flights in an effort to have their joint marketing plan approved.

headline: Free Checking Could Go the Way of Free Toasters
abstract: Overdraft fees had helped to subsidize free checking, but as those fees begin to fall, free checking may disappear.

headline: Wall St.’s Biggest Bonuses Go to Not-So-Big Names
abstract: Bonus watchers focused on Goldman’s chief, but he was eclipsed by executives outside the old pecking order of pay.

headline: Judging Stimulus by Job Data Reveals Success

abstract: The approval of China and Russia is still needed for Oracle to complete its takeover of Sun Microsystems.

headline: Radiation Levels Cloud Vermont Reactor’s Fate
abstract: Longtime supporters and foes of the state’s only atomic power plant are questioning whether its operating license will be extended past 2012.

headline: Baghdad Blasts Shatter Sense of Security in Capital
abstract: Three bombs exploded outside major hotels in Baghdad, including one used by Western journalists, stirring fears of escalating violence as Iraq heads toward elections.

abstract: Leaders have agreed on a statement but left the details to be worked out by finance ministers Monday.

headline: China: Film Star Responds to Accusations on Quake Charity
abstract: Zhang Ziyi, the best-known Chinese actress internationally, has denied accusations that she committed fraud while trying to raise money for earthquake victims.

headline: Ethiopian Airliner Crashes Near Beirut
abstract: The plane crashed into the Mediterranean Sea shortly after takeoff. Reports said that 90 people were on board.

headline: Henry Kissinger Is Released From Hospital in South Korea
abstract: The former United States secretary of state was released after treatment for stomach pains, a spokesman for the hospital said.

abstract: The new restrictions would apply to any stock whose price has fallen at least 10 percent during a day’s session.

abstract: The deaths of seven C.I.A. operatives in Afghanistan have highlighted the agency’s transformation to a paramilitary organization at the vanguard of America’s wars.

abstract: Duraflame is trying to attract women who are “looking for an easy and safe solution to create that cozy, warm house.”

abstract: Dmitri O. Rogozin has rarely been one for niceties in his two years as Russia’s envoy to NATO headquarters in Brussels, famously hanging a portrait of Stalin in his office when he arrived.

abstract: Investigators looking into Web attacks on Google traced the intrusions to Jiaotong University and Lanxiang Vocational School, elite Chinese schools with strong American ties.

abstract: Convoys of farmers in pickup trucks and busloads of families wearing the protesters’ trademark red shirts blanketed a district of ministries and government offices.

abstract: Canadian retail sales rose in January, as consumers stocked up on home improvement supplies before a federal tax credit expired.

abstract: High debt levels are causing states to take desperate measures to make their finances appear healthy.

abstract: A veteran of Wall Street says people of all levels of wealth have come to view their assets differently after the financial crisis.

abstract: DoubleTree Hotels and Midwest Airlines serve up chocolate chip cookies, a sweet reminder that they’re different from other brands.

abstract: The most striking aspect of a new U.N. report was the shift in responsibility for the deaths of Afghan civilians.

abstract: The state would lose billions of dollars in future revenue under a bill to share oil royalties equally among Brazil’s states.

abstract: Ali Ibrahim el-Soudany, 36, who preached at several mosques in the troubled suburbs of Paris, was expelled to his country of origin.

abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and TPG Capital have tentatively agreed to pay close to $1 billion to acquire Morgan Stanley’s stake in China’s leading investment bank.

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on Wednesday about a new effort by the United States and other countries to help stabilize Yemen, which is threatened by poverty, insurgency and Al Qaeda militants, misstated the year that Edmund J. Hull, a former United States ambassador to Yemen, first traveled to that country’s more dangerous areas in an earlier American effort to foster aid projects. It was 2002, not 2003.

headline: Turning Patents Into ‘Invention Capital’
abstract: Intellectual Ventures has acquired 30,000 patents and has so far collected more than $1 billion in license fees.

headline: Dutch Pull-Out From War Expected After Government Collapse
abstract: A day after his government collapsed, Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende said he expected Dutch troops to come home from Afghanistan this year.

headline: Imaginary Chats and Texts When a Quick Getaway Is in Order
abstract: Apps for making fake calls and texts can help April 1 pranksters pull off a joke and serve a useful purpose beyond the holiday.

headline: Deborah Howell, One of the First Women to Lead a Big U.S. Paper, Dies at 68
abstract: Ms. Howell was an ombudsman of The Washington Post and a top editor, who earned accolades for her toughness, curiosity and enthusiasm.

headline: Preparing for the Inevitable Bursting Bubble
abstract: There’s bound to be another bubble and another one after that. A way to survive their collapses is to honestly assess your long-term goals.

abstract: Hoping to increase Venezuela’s flagging oil production and pull the country out of a sharp economic downturn, President Hugo Chavez awarded major oil contracts to U.S. firms.

abstract: The report, by Amnesty International, found that migrant workers faced widespread abuse, and accused the government of not doing enough to protect them.

abstract: An order signed by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton would allow Tariq Ramadan and Adam Habib to travel to the United States.

abstract: Pakistani authorities said about a dozen masked militants stormed the building at about 9:30 a.m., herded staff members into a room, and started shooting indiscriminately.

abstract: The supermarket chain’s profit topped Wall Street’s forecast of 34 cents a share, and its sales were better than the $17.7 billion analysts expected.

abstract: The first Chinese trial involving organ trafficking could take place next month in Beijing, according to a report in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

headline: Travel Sites or Guidebooks: Why Not Dip Into Both?
abstract: Where do you turn when looking for reliable, practical travel information — online or in print? The answer is all of the above, because one complements the other.

abstract: The Italian police have arrested seven people accused of illegally selling arms to Iran via Eastern Europe, the authorities said Wednesday.

abstract: The crash, which involved a Boeing 737 operated by a domestic subsidiary of Aeroflot, killed all 88 people aboard.

abstract: Dr. Timothy R. Kuklo, who was accused of lying about bone-growth research, would have to be called back to active duty to face such a trial.

abstract: Many new airlines struggle to get access to runway slots and terminal gates at some of the nation’s biggest and busiest airports.

abstract: Opposition to the president’s plan to tap foreign currency reserves led her to dismiss the central bank’s head, a move blocked by a federal judge.

abstract: The fate of a Northern Irish leader who is struggling to recover from revelations about his wife is crucial to a power-sharing agreement’s future.

abstract: Many cellular operators block Skype’s calls, or outlaw the use of VoIP service in their contracts.

abstract: An Israeli Embassy vehicle was the target of a roadside bomb in Jordan on Thursday, but the explosion caused no injuries, the Israeli Foreign Ministry said

abstract: Issues like inflation and interest rate policy played roles in the administration putting forth names like Janet L. Yellen to be considered for the bank’s board of governors.

abstract: An association representing 300 large companies said a provision of the health overhaul would hurt profits.

abstract: Online social networks have become valuable sources of information and camaraderie for people with chronic diseases or disabilities.

abstract: Mr. Bankier, who was the head of the International Institute for Holocaust Research, examined the participation of ordinary Europeans in the extermination of their Jewish neighbors.

abstract: Apple does not exhibit at trade fairs, only at its own staged events. But many items on display in Spain complement or respond to the company’s wares.

abstract: The vote turned into a referendum of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s conservative style, and his coalition managed to wrest four regions from the opposition.

headline: Brown and Party Show Signs of Life
abstract: Once thought doomed to lead Labour to defeat, Prime Minister Gordon Brown may avoid that fate as polls show a swing toward Labour as a vote nears.

abstract: The statements appeared to be part of a renewed campaign by the opposition’s leadership to prove that they were still vital, despite a brutal crackdown by the government.

abstract: Amid calls to restrict oversight by the Federal Reserve, its chairman told the Senate that new limits would undermine monetary policy.

abstract: Hurt by falling revenue and an uncertain economic outlook, European airlines have taken a hard line on costs.

abstract: James P. Gorman wants to build a steadier, more diversified Morgan Stanley, and avoid risky megatrades.

headline: Sales Fall at American Apparel
abstract: American Apparel said sales at its existing stores fell in the fourth quarter and will fall further this year.

headline: Financial Perversions Sold During Credit Boom

abstract: Senior Israeli ministers have publicly rejected American demands for curbs on Jewish building in East Jerusalem.

headline: Bankers in Davos Seek a United Message on Volcker Rule
abstract: At the World Economic Forum, contentious discussions centered on President Obama’s plan to restrict proprietary trading.

headline: Russia: Life Term for a Former Officer
abstract: A former police major who went on a shooting rampage last year at a Moscow supermarket, killing two people and wounding others, was sentenced to life in prison.

abstract: Several civilians were killed in Paktia Province on Friday when a joint Afghan-NATO force went to investigate a report of militant activity, but NATO and the Afghan police gave varying accounts of what happened.

abstract: New ads From Saks Fifth Avenue, while nodding to a Depression-era column from Harper’s Bazaar, are meant to “make light of things, not be so ponderous and heavy,” an executive said.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A headline on Monday about successful emergency surgery performed on Néstor Kirchner, the former president of Argentina, misidentified the procedure he underwent. Doctors unclogged his right carotid artery, which carries blood from the aorta to the head; they did not perform “heart surgery.”

headline: Regulators Tackle ‘Carry Trades’
abstract: As governments seek to root out and smother what they see as excessively risky and questionable financial market activity, the world of currency “carry trades” has found its way onto their radar.

headline: A Day of Surprises at the First Practice Sessions in Bahrain
abstract: The first Formula One practice session of the day was full of surprises as the season began at the Bahrain Grand Prix.
